page.title: 06River Tamar _ Physical
page.content: The River Tamar is tidal and forms a natural boundary between Devon and Cornwall. The{landscape}of this part of the river consists of mainly water meadows and saltings, with a larger number of mud flats on the Cornish side, and several gravelly beaches on the Devon bank. Here small areas of deciduous woodland slope down to the water's edge, adding to the{scenery}. There are many small creeks, some now reclaimed, with a silted-up quay at Pentillie, and a dammed creek making a small inland lake at Haye. Of great interest are the various Quays, once very busy with river traffic, but now mostly unused, apart from{moorings}for yachts and houseboats. At Halton, Clifton, Hole's Hole and Pentillie the remains of lime kilns and other industrial ruins point to the{local {history}of the area.
